newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Ukraine, with less Turkmen gas, may revamp buying.
newsitem.headline: Ukraine, with less Turkmen gas, may revamp buying.

text.p: Turkmenistan, which cut gas supplies to Ukraine last week, may force changes in Ukraine's gas import system but will not dent Kiev's energy-hungry economy, energy analysts said on Tuesday.
Turkmen President Saparmurat Niyazov said last week that his desert Central Asian state had cut all gas supplies to Ukraine because of unpaid bills.
The cut could be the first real challenge to Ukraine's gas import scheme, in which trading companies are approved by the government to contract for gas supplies.
The scheme is supposed to introduce more competition to the market, but it has led some traders to say there is not enough transparency and competitiveness.
"The cut could lead to changes in the system of gas imports from Russia and from Central Asia and gas distribution here," one analyst said.
Ukraine still owes about $200 million to Turkmenistan for supplies delivered before 1996.
Analysts said that around a dozen of Ukraine's gas traders owe Russian and Turkmen exporters $272 million for supplies in 1995-1997.
Niyazov blamed the cut on trading companies supplying Ukraine, while Ukraine's president, Leonid Kuchma, promised on Monday to develop closer links with Turkmenistan to buy gas on longterm contracts.
Most of Ukraine's Turkmen gas imports are carried out by Itera-Ukraine, a joint venture with Itera International Energy Corp.
Kuchma said Itera was to supply Ukraine with 11.1 billion cubic metres this year.
An Itera spokesman said at the weekend that the row with Turkmenistan was linked to differences in interpreting contracts, but declined to give further details.
"Let the supplies stop -- there is enough gas here," one Ukrainian gas trader said, adding that Ukraine had about two billion cubic metres of Turkmen gas in storage.
"The main threat -- a cold winter -- is over and there is no danger anymore."
Under a government-sponsored scheme set up in 1995, private and state companies are selected to supply gas to Ukraine and to collect debts for unpaid gas.
The government had hoped the scheme would help it to pay off its debts to the Russian gas monopoly, Gazprom GAZP.RTS.
Kiev still owes $1.5 billion for Russian supplies over 1993 and 1994 but this debt has been rescheduled.
But opponents to the gas distribution scheme say that the scheme -- which thrives on barter payments -- has helped to fuel a payments crisis which left $2.2 billion in salaries and pensions unpaid.
Ukraine is one of the world's largest gas importers.
In addition to Turkmen gas, Kiev is also due this year to import 53 billion culic metres from Gazprom as well as up to 10 billion cubic metres from Uzbekistan.
Kiev's annual gas output is 18 billion cubic metres.
Kuchma has criticised the gas trading scheme as not being competitive enough and has welcomed Niyazov's suggestion that the two countries sign a deal on long-term supplies.
